title: What is Extinction Rebellion and what are they trying to achieve?
text:
Extinction Rebellion use non-violent civil disobedience to achieve their aims (Picture: REUTERS/Peter Nicholls)

Extinction Rebellion protestors have been dragged from the top of trains by angry commuters after targeting the London underground this morning.

Parts of the Jubilee line shut down as fights broke out between passengers and climate activists who climbed on top of trains at Canning Town Station.

Today’s action comes ahead of a High Court hearing over a Met Police ‘ban’ on the group’s disruptive style protests.

But who are Extinction Rebellion and what exactly are they aiming to achieve?

What is Extinction Rebellion?

Advertisement

Advertisement

Extinction Rebellion (XR) describe themselves as an environmental campaign group that uses non-violent civil disobedience ‘in an attempt to halt mass extinction and minimise the risk of social collapse.’

They formed in the UK in October 2018 and say they now have groups all around the world including Spain, South Africa and India.

They hit the headlines in April when they launched a two week ‘international rebellion’ to urge governments around the world to take action on the climate crisis, leading to over 1,000 arrests and bringing parts of London to a standstill.

Their protests included blocking major bridges across the River Thames and super-gluing themselves to the gates of Buckingham Palace.

What do Extinction Rebellion want?

Extinction Rebellion have three demands for the UK.

They are: ‘Tell the truth’ by declaring a climate emergency, ‘Act Now’ to halt biodiversity loss and reduce greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by 2025 and go ‘Beyond Politics’ by establishing a citizens assembly to combat climate change.

Advertisement

Advertisement

A citizen’s assembly would see people randomly selected from across the country, similar to jury service, to discuss and make recommendations on how to respond to the climate emergency.

A protester hands out leaflets in the South Terminal at Gatwick Airport during an Extinction Rebellion (XR) climate change protest (Picture: PA)

Climate activists protest outside the Supreme Court, during the eleventh day of demonstrations in London this month (Picture: AFP)

Will their demands be met?

In May MPs voted to declare a climate emergency, but the group claim this is ‘symbolic and non-binding’.

Ministers have also pledged to produce net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 but XR say that target is ‘a generation too late’.

The government also announced plans for a citizens assembly in June, but again the group said this did not go far enough, as members could only make recommendations.

However, some climate experts have said the groups demands are unrealistic, particularly getting to zero emissions by 2025.

Researchers at the Centre for Alternative Technology said for this to be achieved, flights would have to be restricted and people would have to drastically change their behaviour – such as eating less meat and changing how they travel.

Advertisement

However, co-founder of the group Gail Bradbrook say the government have left it so late to deal with the climate crisis that society has to step up in a ‘semi-miraculous way’.

What have Extinction Rebellion been doing?

To highlight their message, XR protestors have glued themselves to trains, blocked traffic, chained themselves outside politicians’ houses and planted trees outside parliament.

Activists climb down from the awning over the Brazilian Embassy’s entrance during Extinction Rebellion climate change protest in London (Picture: REUTERS)

Protestors disrupt the tube network by climbing on top of Canning Town underground station (Picture: Extinction Rebellion)

More recently, breastfeeding mothers and their babies blockaded Google’s London HQ calling for the tech giant to stop funding climate change deniers.

Extinction Rebellion activists also stood outside YouTube’s nearby Kings Cross offices in protest against them giving a platform to people who reject science on global warming.

Meanwhile some 1,000 protesters sat down in Trafalgar Square in defiance of controversial Metropolitan Police ban on all of the group’s demonstrations in the capital.

More than 1,600 protesters have been arrested since the recent wave of protests began on October 7, 133 of whom have been charged.

Advertisement

Extinction Rebellion have been open about their tactics to overwhelm the capacity of policy custody, including by refusing bail after being arrested.

They are encouraging people to risk going to prison so their demands can be heard.
